Award.AbstractNarration:
The Center for Chemical Evolution (CCE) coordinates and supports the highly collaborative research necessary to understand the chemistry required for the spontaneous emergence of functional polymers, such as proteins and DNA, from complex chemical mixtures. An interdisciplinary team of researchers will tackle this grand challenge using a three-pronged strategy: 1) Construct a working model chemical inventory of potentially prebiotic molecules and understand their reactivity; 2) Explore alternative reactions and solvent conditions that could have facilitated polymerization in the prebiotic world; and 3) Synthesize and characterize putative proto-biopolymers as a means to discover which building blocks and polymer architectures might have preceded those found in life today. When combined in one Center, synergy across these themes will accelerate our understanding of the emergent properties of matter -- properties that underpin chemical evolution and provide the foundations for the origins of biology. Understanding the spontaneous assembly of functional polymers will lead to new structures, reactions, and assemblies with applications that span the fields of organic, polymer, supramolecular, and biomimetic chemistry; new analytical tools and approaches for dealing with complex chemical mixtures; and an insight into matter and reactivity that will impact areas of both pure and applied chemistry.

Chemical evolution experiments have a broad and unique ability to excite students and the general public about the power of chemistry to see into our distant past. The Center will educate a diverse group of students at all levels. Graduate students and postdoctoral fellows will have access to professional development opportunities in teaching and public communication. The Center will increase participation of underrepresented groups by partnering with specific undergraduate institutions and by providing access to Center research through both direct and videoconference interactions. Center researchers will collaborate with high school teachers and faculty at primarily undergraduate institutions to develop and distribute chemical evolution modules for incorporation into introductory and organic chemistry courses. The Center sees the misconceptions of chemical and biological evolution as a critical public outreach opportunity, and it has identified unique educational and public venues to promote science literacy and enthusiasm for pursuing careers in the chemical sciences. Center researchers and students will make major impacts on the public's perception of chemistry by working with artists who are creating new science-inspired performing and visual works of art, promoting publicly accessible informal talks in the form of "Science Caf√©s," and contributing to national websites and education centers on chemical and evolution education. The development of new analytical tools, environmentally benign solvent systems, and biomimetic emergent polymers will be widely disseminated in partnership with the private sector.

The Center for Chemical Evolution is jointly funded by the NSF Centers for Chemical Innovation Program and the NASA Astrobiology Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Center for Chemical Evolution (CCE) was founded to support and coordinate the highly collaborative, interdisciplinary research that is necessary to ultimately uncover the chemistry that potentially gave rise to life on Earth. More specifically, research within the CCE has focused on understanding how the earliest polymers of life could have spontaneously formed from smaller molecules presumed available on the prebiotic Earth. Beyond the evolution of biopolymers, CCE research has also resulted in important advances in organic, polymer, analytical, supramolecular and biomimetic chemistry with potential applications in the development of new materials, therapeutic agents, and environmentally-friendly chemical processes. CCE research focus on the origin of three main classes of biopolymers: 1) polypeptides, 2) nucleic acids and 3) polysaccharides.

            Proteins, or polypeptides, are the “workhorse” molecules of life. In living cells proteins are synthesized by the formation of peptide bonds between chemically activated amino acids. Amino acids were reported among the products of Stanley Miller’s spark-discharge experiments in 1953. Since that time chemists have sought to determine how polypeptides could have formed on the early Earth, before the emergence of the complex molecular machinery that synthesizes polypeptides in contemporary life. A number of prebiotic reactions previously proposed promote peptide bond formation, but the yields are typically lower than 2%, and the peptides produced very short (dimers, trimers). In addition, some of these reactions required activating chemical reagents that were not likely common on the early Earth. CCE researchers have discovered an environmental “ratcheting” mechanism where condensation reactions between amino acids and hydroxy acids result in the production of depsipeptides (polymers containing both ester and amide bonds), a process that could have been driven by the diurnal cycle on the prebiotic Earth. The finding of hydroxy and amino acids in model prebiotic reactions and in meteorites supports the hypothesis that depsipeptides could have been ancestors of polypeptides, with the conversion to polypeptides through chemical and/or biological evolution. CCE researchers have demonstrated a mechanism where depsipeptide synthesis is efficient, resulting in virtually all of the starting amino acids becoming incorporated into depsipeptides and chains as long as 18 units. Because depsipeptides are also used in commercial and medical applications, the depsipeptide synthesis may also be leveraged for the more cost effective production of such materials. Furthermore, the analytical techniques developed within the CCE for the analysis of depsipeptide product mixtures could see applications in areas of societal and scientific importance (e.g., medical diagnostics, ‘-omics’).

         Nucleic acids (RNA and DNA) are the informational polymers of life. Because RNA can act as both a material for information storage and as a chemical catalyst, researchers have hypothesized for decades that RNA might have been first to occur. However, despite considerable effort, a plausible prebiotic synthesis for RNA had not yet been found. Guided by the hypothesis that an alternative, but related molecule preceded RNA, CCE researchers have discovered that molecules with chemical structures similar to the RNA nucleobases (the “pairing parts” of RNA), readily react with ribose (the sugar of RNA) to form a chemical structure that looks like a potential precursor of an ancestral nucleic acid. This model “proto-nucleoside” assembles in water with another plausible proto-nucleobase to form long supramolecular assemblies that resemble precursors to gene-length RNA polymers. These model proto-RNA precursors cause water gelation in a pH-dependent manner, a property that is useful in the creation of ‘smart’ materials that respond to minute changes in the acidity of a local environment. These discoveries have implications for the development of environmentally responsive materials, which are of interest in drug delivery, among other applications.

            Carbohydrates (e.g., sugars, sugar acids, etc.) and polysaccharides are central to the metabolism, energy storage and cellular structure of living organisms. The original source of these molecules during the earliest stages of life on Earth has presented a conundrum for chemists. It has been known for over two hundred years that formaldehyde can form a wide range of carbohydrates in the so-called “formose reaction.” Furthermore, the identification of formaldehyde in interstellar space, has fueled much speculation about the potential importance of the formose reaction in the origin of life. However, the reaction conditions and the clutter of molecules produced by the formose reaction have led to searches for alternative building blocks and reaction pathways. CCE researchers have discovered that glyoxylate, a potentially prebiotic small molecule utilized in the metabolism of living organisms, can also act as a source material for the production of sugars and several molecules that are utilized in the metabolism of contemporary organisms. Exploration of the reactions that transform glyoxylate into sugars, sugar acids, and metabolic carbohydrates have revealed previously unrecognized organic reactions that could facilitate the development of more efficient and more environmentally friendly (green) chemistry, advantageous for the synthesis of specialty chemicals of commercial importance.
